anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there can be nodoubt that the general principle of res judicata applies to writ petitions filed under Art. 32 or Art. 226. It is necessary to emphasise that the application of the doctrine

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents in Pandit M.S.M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha and Daryao v. State of U.P., general res judicata binds even Art.32/226 petitions on same matter after contest.

holdings.text: Where the liability of a tax for a particular year is considered and decided, the decision for that particular year does not operate as res judicata in respect of the liability for a subsequent year

anchor.surface_text: Where the liability of a tax for a particular year is considered and decided, does the decision for that particular year operate as res judicata in respect of the liability for a subsequent year ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax liability yearly distinct cause of action; supported by English cases like Society of Medical Officers, Broken Hill, distinguishing Hoystead; policy favors no estoppel in recurring tax assessments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constructive res judicata artificial under CPC s.11, reluctant to extend to writs especially different years; prior decision did not consider merits of rate increase; new grounds raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair (confiscatory, no quasi-judicial); here Rules 3-10 provide assessment, objections, finality, based on assessee data.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the demand of the tax 9 pies per ton is invalid, because it is inconsistent with Rule 3 which has prescribed the maximum rate permissible to be levied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 3 deleted by notification Sept 6, 1943; appellants conceded; s.79(1)(xv) allowed max rate rules but deleted.

holdings.text: the impost of the tax at 9 pies per ton is invalid because it does not comply with s.51(2) requiring previous sanction of Provincial Government for first imposition including rate increases

anchor.surface_text: It is then argued that the impost of the tax at the rate of 9 pies per ton is not valid, because it does not comply with the requirements of s. 51(2) of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'First imposition' includes rate increases post Rule 3 deletion (no ceiling); requires sanction per s.51(2) read with s.79; notifications show no prior sanction, only board resolutions.

holdings.text: it is not open to the respondent to reopen assessments already made and rendered final under Rule 10

anchor.surface_text: There is yet another point on which the appellants are entitled to succeed, and that has reference to the fact that the respondent is seeking to reopen some of the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 10 makes Chairman/Board decision final after objections; no provision like IT Act s.34/35 for reopening; finality binds both sides.

holdings.text: the impugned notices seeking recovery of tax at 9 pies per ton are invalid; respondent restrained from recovering above 3 pies per ton (sanctioned rate) or additional tax on past assessed years

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals and the writ petitions are allowed and an appropriate direction or order is issued restraining the respondent from recovering the tax at a rate higher than 3 pies

holdings.reasoning_summary: Composite application: no s.51(2) sanction for increases; Rule 10 bars reopening; 3 pies valid per 1935 sanction.
